inlineContent.text: , making UI development maintainable, flexible and powerful while retaining a close connection with underlying frameworks
; and seamless integration with Apple’s flagship framework
optimizes UI development in the general case, using declarative and reactive paradigms, but still allows developers to solve problems the “hard way” when necessary, using the imperative approach.

inlineContent.text: Use “live” layouts that automatically update on size, orientation or color scheme change. No imperative updates or layout constraints required. Simply conform to
and create the UI using deterministic layout operators.

code: func live(update: Update) { // Create view's layout
// Fit header to leading in portrait and to top in landscape
func live(update: Update) { // Create header layout
func live(update: Update) { // Create list layout

inlineContent.text: Abstract away the look and feel of apps via themes, which could even exist in a separate file, maintained by designers.

code: applyTheme() // Apply theme to this view
func live(data page: Model, update: Update) {
applyTheme() // Apply theme to this sub-view

inlineContent.text: This documentation is a work-in-progress. The following is an alphabetic list of all public classes, structures, enums, protocols, functions, operators and type aliases. It’s big. Fortunately, actual project structure and API completions/documentation make C3UI easy to use in practice.

abstract.text: is a Swift framework for developing apps on iOS and iPadOS.
Protocol for objects that can be automatically identified
based on another object or itself. Override any method
to control how that identification occurs.
A view representing a background than can use autolayout constraints.
Attach the current query of items to it’s query reference preserving
the relative position in the new parent item - via originNormalized().
This operator is not animatable. However, to simulate animation of this change,
set the new parent item as a reference item, animate the change (e.g.
originToReference, centering, etc), then in the animation completion handler
run attachToReference() to complete the transition to the new hierarchy.
This method support attaching across divergent types (e.g. attaching
a Button to a View), which is different than attach() which does
support this.

Add two optional floats. If the left value is non-nil
will return that value or that value + right value,
else nil. This operator does not treat left and right
sides equally as does a traditional binary +. Left
side
be non-nil in order to return non-nil.
i.e. if left is nil, right value is ignored.
l   +? r   = l + r
l   +? nil = l
nil +? r   = nil

nil + nil  = nil (not 0.0)

Align the edge of queried items to an anchor item. Anchor may be
specified via closure from the current query or as a compatible
reference item. Otherwise, it will default to aligning everything
to the first item.
To align to parent item (in case of diverse alignments) return
parent from anchor closure, e.g. align(..) { $0.parent }.
The relation must be the same type as the item type. If this is a problem
then cast the query to the most general type, e.g.
Providing one edge will align both items and anchor on that edge.
Providing an additional anchor edge will align the item edge to
the anchor edge. For example, align(.top) will align the top edge
of each item to the top edge of the anchor item (similar to “pin”).
Wheras, align(.top, with:.bottom) will align the top edge of each
item with the bottom edge of the anchor item.
Positive offsets add spacing
from origin (toward bottom-trailing).
Offset respects layout direction (i.e. it goes
origin).
“Offset” is not to be confused with “insets”.
Use .flex option to align a “flexible” edge to any other attribute
while maintaining the position of the opposite edge, effectively
stretching the item from the opposite edge to the alignment edge.
See also other align() method for more specialized alignments.

Clamp a number to be between minimum and maximum
inclusive. Example: 50% >=< 100…200 will
return 50% of the input value if it’s greater than
